intro: Didissandra longipes, commonly known as the long-stemmed didissandra, is a member of the Araliaceae family and is native to tropical regions of South America. It is a climbing plant characterized by its slender, woody stems and compound leaves with elongated, lance-shaped lobes. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers arranged in umbels, followed by yellowish berries that are toxic to humans. It thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in rainforests. Due to its unique morphology and ecological role, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
